titleStmt.title: SII 2.23: original edition by Eugen Julius Theodor Hultzsch
No. 23. ON THE SOUTH WALL, FIRST TIER.

summary.p: This inscription contains an order of king Tirumalaidēva, by which a number of villages were exempted from taxes. This was probably done, because they had been granted to the Tañjāvūr temple. The date of the inscription is Śaka 1377 (expired), the cyclic year Yuvan, i.e., A.D. 1455. Consequently, the king to whose reign it belongs, must be distinct from the Karṇāṭa king Tirumalaidēva, whose four inscriptions near Vēlūr are dated in Śaka 1488 (expired).Vol. I, page 69 f. Read there Tirumalaidēva for Tirumalaiyadēva, and in the transcripts of Nos. 13 to 16 tirumalaiydeva for tirumalaiya deva. It is not impossible that Tirumalaidēva is identical with Timma, the founder of the second dynasty of Vijayanagara, for whose grandson Narasa, Nṛisiṁha or Narasiṁha we have the dates Śaka 1404 and 1418.Vol. I, p. 132, No. 119, and p. 131, No. 115; Epigraphia Indica, p. 362. In favour of this identification it can be adduced, that in the subjoined inscription, Tirumalaidēva receives the same birudas which were borne by Narasiṁhadēva according to an inscription at Viriñchipuram,Vol. I, p. 132, No. 119. and that some of the fiscal terms, which occur in the text of the royal order, are of Kanarese extraction.

Both the spelling and the execution of this inscription are not very careful.Plate xix in Dr. Burnell's South-Indian Palaeography, second edition, is based on this inscription. The table contains three mistakes:—The sign entered as ā is not ā, but a vicarious form of a; the sign entered as kū is not kū , but ku; and the sign entered as ḷu is not ḷu, but nnya (Grantha nnya). Lines 2 to 6 are damaged by a crack, which has caused the loss of a few letters. The language is Tamil, with the exception of line 1, which consists of a Sanskrit ślōka.

1. “Of a gift and protection, protection is more meritorious than a gift; by a gift (one) obtains (only) heaven, by protection the eternal abode.”

2. Let there be prosperity ! Fortune ! [On the 17th day] of the month of Śittirai in the Yuvan year, which was current after the Bhāva year (and) after the Śaka year one thousand three hundred and seventy-seven, the illustrious Mahāmaṇḍalēśvara Mēdinīśvara Gaṇḍa Kaṭṭāri Sāḷuva-sāḷuva Tirumalaidēva-mahārāja (addressed the following) order (nirubam) to Vāriyaṉ, the Kāraṇattāṉkāraṇattāṉ is another form of, or a mistake for, karaṇattāṉ, which is used instead of karaṇam, ‘a village-accountant,’ in a Māmallapuram inscription, Vol. I, No. 40, text line 60. in the village (agaram) of Tañjāvūr, • • • • • • , Ta[ñ]jamāmaṇigaṇḍaṅguṟai, Nāgaḷāpuram, Paramāṟaṉēri, Vēlaṅguḍi, (which was) the chief village (of a division) of fifty (villages),Another division of fifty villages is mentioned in two Māmallapuram inscriptions, Vol. I, No. 40, text line 16, and No. 41, text line 33. Ammaia[ppapu]ram, Teṉaḷūr, Karuppūr, Maruvūr,According to Mr. Sewell's Lists (Vol. I, p. 276), Karuppūr and Maruvūr are the names of two villages in the Tañjāvūr tālluqa. Rājēndra-Śōṛa-nallūr, Śuṅgandavi[r]tta-Śōṛa-nallūr,This village is the object of the grant recorded in No. 22. alias Tirumalairājapuram, and Samudra • • • puram:—

3. “Having remitted to your villages • • • • • the prime minister's quit-rent (pradhāni-jōḍi),See Sanderson's Canarese Dictionary, s.v. jōḍi. the Karaṇam's quit-rent (karaṇikka-jōḍi), the village-watchman's quitrent,talaiyārikkam seems to be the Tamil equivalent of the Kanarese term taḷavāṟike, which occurs in a Vijayanagara inscription of Kṛishṇarāya; Epigraphia Indica, p. 402, note 40. (the dues on) animals, trees and tanks,On māvaṭai maravaṭai kuḷavaṭai see p. 117, note 6. and all other dues (? upādhi) of whatever kind, (we order that these villages) to the extent up to which they were granted, shall remain taxfree (sarvamānya) and undisturbed, as long as the moon and the sun endure.”
4. Mantramūrti caused (the above) to be engraved, as ordered by the king.
